ideas:
[Evaluation] Dynamic Attention Network for Visual Scene Understanding

This research explores a novel dynamic attention mechanism for visual scene understanding, aiming to improve performance on complex scenes with occlusions and varying object scales. The idea involves extending the standard self-attention mechanism to incorporate a "contextual memory" layer that dynamically adjusts the attention weights based on recent visual input. We will evaluate the network on a dataset of human-annotated scenes with varying levels of occlusion and object scale using metrics like Mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) and a custom metric measuring the accuracy of object segmentation.

[Cognitive Science] Exploring the Role of Predictive Coding in Social Memory Consolidation

This research investigates how predictive coding mechanisms influence the consolidation of social memories – memories of interactions with others. I will build a simulated environment where participants are presented with a series of social interactions, and then receive a "prediction" of the likely outcome of the interaction.  The goal is to determine if participants exhibit increased memory consolidation when they receive a more accurate prediction, compared to a less accurate one. Data will include EEG recordings to measure neural activity associated with prediction and consolidation, and a subjective rating of memory recall accuracy. Metrics will include accuracy of recall and subjective ratings of emotional intensity.

[Safety] Bias Detection in Personalized Recommendation Systems

This research will develop a novel method for detecting subtle biases embedded within personalized recommendation systems by analyzing the diversity of items presented to users. I will build a system that identifies when a user consistently receives recommendations that are highly similar to those they’ve previously engaged with, even if those recommendations are not explicitly biased. Data will include user interaction history, item metadata, and a measure of similarity between items. Evaluation will involve comparing the system’s detection rate to human annotators and assessing the impact on user satisfaction.

[NLP] Contextualized Sentiment Analysis of Social Media Posts

This research explores the development of a novel contextualized sentiment analysis model that goes beyond simple polarity detection by incorporating discourse-level cues and emotional tone. The model will be trained on a large dataset of social media posts, utilizing a transformer architecture augmented with a discourse parsing module. Evaluation will be based on a combination of accuracy (measured by F1-score) and a novel metric called “Emotional Resonance Score” which quantifies the degree to which the model’s sentiment prediction aligns with the expressed emotional tone of the post.

[NLP] Text-Image Fusion for Enhanced Dialogue Understanding

This research explores the use of a joint embedding space to represent text and visual cues in dialogue, aiming to improve the accuracy of dialogue systems by allowing them to better understand the context and intent of a user’s message. We will train a model to map text descriptions to corresponding visual representations, then use this fused representation to predict the next utterance. Evaluation will be based on a benchmark dataset of multi-modal dialogue, measuring metrics like coherence and relevance.

[NLP] Contextualized Sentiment Analysis with Implicit Belief Modeling

This research investigates a method for improving sentiment analysis by incorporating implicit beliefs about the topic being discussed. It will develop a model that learns to predict the user's underlying beliefs about a given text, rather than solely relying on explicit sentiment labels. The model will utilize a transformer architecture and incorporate a knowledge graph to represent and reason about the topic's context. Evaluation will be based on a held-out dataset of text with known implicit beliefs and a separate test set measuring the accuracy of predicting these beliefs.

[NLP] Contextualized Sentiment Analysis of Social Media Posts

This research explores the development of a novel contextualized sentiment analysis model that goes beyond simple polarity detection by incorporating discourse-level cues and emotional tone. The model will be trained on a large dataset of social media posts, utilizing a transformer architecture augmented with a discourse parsing module to identify key phrases and relationships between sentences. Evaluation will be based on a held-out test set measuring accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, comparing against a baseline model trained on standard sentiment analysis techniques.

[Evaluation] Dynamic Attention Mechanism for Visual Question Answering

This research explores a novel dynamic attention mechanism for visual question answering (VQA) that adapts attention weights based on the temporal coherence of the visual input and the question. Current VQA models often struggle with long-range dependencies and inconsistent reasoning. We will develop a mechanism that learns to prioritize relevant visual features and question components, improving accuracy and robustness. Data will be a dataset of images paired with questions and answers, and evaluation will be based on accuracy on a held-out test set and a user study measuring coherence of answers. Metrics will include Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR) and human evaluation of answer quality.

[NLP] Contextualized Sentiment Analysis of Social Media Posts for Proactive Crisis Detection

This research will develop a novel system for identifying potential social media crises by analyzing the sentiment expressed within posts related to a specific event or topic. The system will utilize a transformer-based model fine-tuned on a labeled dataset of social media posts, incorporating a novel attention mechanism to focus on the most emotionally charged words and phrases. Evaluation will be based on precision and recall for detecting emerging crisis indicators, as well as a user-defined metric of time to detection.

[Safety] Algorithmic Bias Detection in Autonomous Vehicle Perception Systems

This research will develop a novel framework for detecting and quantifying algorithmic bias in pedestrian detection models used by autonomous vehicles. The framework will leverage a combination of adversarial training and explainable AI (XAI) techniques to identify disparities in detection rates across demographic groups (e.g., based on age, race, and gender). We will evaluate the framework using a publicly available dataset of pedestrian images and metrics such as precision, recall, and F1-score, focusing on identifying patterns indicative of biased model behavior.
